Result from x.com","url":"https://x.com/Tesla/status/1999628353809354898","display_source_type":"X.AI_GROK_X"}},"[cite_index=93]":{"source":["GeminiWebService"],"content":"**Futu Holdings Sees Positive Analyst Sentiment Amidst Broader Chinese Economic Concerns in December 2025**\n\nDuring the first half of December 2025, Futu Holdings (FUTU) garnered positive attention from Wall Street analysts, with a consensus \"Buy\" rating and a mean price target suggesting a potential 27.5% upside. This sentiment follows the company's strong third-quarter 2025 financial results, announced on November 18, 2025, which reported significant year-over-year increases in revenues, gross profit, net income, and client assets. While no new earnings reports were released within the December 1-16 timeframe, the Q3 results provided a robust backdrop for investor confidence.\n\nInstitutional investors showed mixed activity, with National Bank of Canada FI trimming its stake by 5.1%, while other hedge funds and institutional investors, including LFA Lugano Financial Advisors SA, Hantz Financial Services Inc., Geneos Wealth Management Inc., First Horizon Advisors Inc., and SVB Wealth LLC, either bought new stakes or boosted their existing holdings in Futu during the second quarter of 2025.\n\nIn terms of cryptocurrency operations, Futu Securities, a subsidiary of Futu Holdings, received an upgraded Type 1 license in July 2024 from the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) to offer virtual asset dealing services to Hong Kong investors. Furthermore, Futu's subsidiary, Panthertrade, obtained a Virtual Asset Trading Platform License (VATP) in January 2025 and is currently undergoing a second-phase evaluation with the SFC to officially commence operations. Futu also launched zero-commission crypto trading in Hong Kong in August 2024. No new updates on these licenses were reported in early December 2025.\n\n**Chinese Brokerage Regulation and Economic Stimulus**\n\nChinese regulatory bodies continued to refine market access and trading rules. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) announced a plan on October 27, 2025, to streamline the qualified foreign investor regime. This initiative aims to ease access requirements, enhance operational efficiency, and broaden the investment scope for foreign investors, including allowing them to use exchange-traded fund options for hedging and participate in commodity futures and options trading.\n\nRegarding program trading, the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) and Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE) issued new reporting requirements for northbound investors engaged in program trading under the Stock Connect on July 11, 2025. These rules are set to take effect on January 12, 2026, building upon the CSRC's earlier administrative rules and implementation guidelines.\n\nIn Hong Kong, the SFC issued a circular on December 12, 2025, concerning clearing and record-keeping rules for over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives, and another on December 5, 2025, for a joint product survey. These updates contribute to the ongoing regulatory framework for financial services in the region, impacting brokers operating in Hong Kong.\n\nOn the economic front, China's economy showed mixed signals. While the government plans to issue ultra-long-term special government bonds in 2026 to fund national strategies, security initiatives, equipment upgrades, and consumer goods trade-in programs, recent economic data for November 2025 indicated challenges. Weak retail sales and falling house prices raised doubts about Beijing's 5% GDP growth target for 2025. Despite these concerns, there were prospects of further stimulus measures from Beijing and monetary policy easing to cushion the downside. Official comments from the National Bureau of Statistics on December 15, 2025, reinforced expectations for ongoing targeted stimulus to stabilize growth and address external headwinds and domestic imbalances.","display_source_type":"SPECIALIST_TOOL","specialist_name":"fundamental","category":"specialist_tool","metadata":{"is_main_response":true,"model":"gemini-2.5-flash","source_type":"llm_response"}},"[cite_index=94]":{"source":["https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQHr3YOM5zjaFhUaCA-7v8_PHsSQttKCtVYSWm7D9dpGUTwY-Y-KTuhopAlFDVN2cCaWxufzRinSpwJ8k2vPMMEM96AQwZPKNICdFH44tGpCef5S8s3cuCcRWrAAop0lGMeBewuHnBzHWg8fOB4eLRB0-50I3sIiAcVAeWMYdrZvZGvgDg4xAz685qnUBsukOhcG9lI7MzkUmOSLIVHbJEw2z1bQttRYD1PrqO0ckef-5Wkf5uHvub8h-uaKeQWnP7EmjFESfaOy9kvQ","https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQFwZv0RYsP2oBm-9aDGjM7iavck76_OtVCAG6ObKnHHJiScFoVJ3bt2hjIMx9OCWexgwWBajtTgXLapDwxeRM7MhMrzBXqBvn5kJhx7Fff6y0n5SRE0NEkVTSewiEDiX8Na4g3enMcpyxqirO6neQgbdcA0mdB-ZAkhnx99OMsHqNvfztzewtcROqJbl7gkFto98rByYdq3fP9xRoYGOSU_mYTh4b7wqiI9","https://vertexaisearch.cloud.google.com/grounding-api-redirect/AUZIYQHtybgpfp4GIpKxSd4H_XBV4Lu6zI6lAP_pxjjGM6K8plyok--9uO6jYRhIA1FzFllkmeiXZvYS9sEZQ7BI5ac5BB25DoaUj2uNR-OR2kZgA2MXzA2Cl4c0AfcS5ZPGd8IJzhCeEorvlOP_l5INa4fhKT4ahNRxxTiFKjr6L9Gp3pMHbGeNS2kN0snT12QS1VjAbN4MYKYfiti9FTv7gQ5WvSDiSwsJff1l67_g5dDAEXKlr9m47yU="],"content":"This tensions and evolving regulatory landscapes in both the United States and China are poised to significantly impact China ADRs and Hong Kong Fintech in late 2025. Key risks include the ongoing threat of delisting for China ADRs, new and expanded US investment bans, and a series of regulatory updates from China's securities regulator affecting overseas listings and market operations.\n\n### China ADR Delisting Risk\n\nThe delisting risk for China ADRs, primarily driven by the US Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act (HFCAA), remains a significant concern for late 2025, although immediate threats have been mitigated. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) gained unprecedented access in 2022 to inspect audit firms in mainland China and Hong Kong, which led to the vacating of previous delisting determinations. This access was a crucial step in allowing Chinese companies to remain listed on US exchanges.\n\nHowever, the risk has not been entirely eliminated. Some analysts, such as TD Cowen and Goldman Sachs, project a rising probability of delisting in 2025, with estimates ranging from 66% to 70%. This renewed concern is attributed to escalating US-China trade tensions and potential policy shifts under a new US administration. For instance, a potential Trump administration's \"America First Investment Policy\" could lead to more aggressive delisting actions as part of broader economic decoupling efforts. Companies with dual listings in Hong Kong are generally considered to have lower exposure to delisting risks, as they offer an alternative trading venue for investors.\n\n### US-China Investment Bans\n\nStringent US investment bans targeting China are already in effect as of January 2025, primarily focusing on sensitive technologies. These restrictions prohibit certain US investments in Chinese companies involved in artificial intelligence (AI), semiconductors, and quantum computing, and require mandatory notifications for other transactions in these sectors. These measures are part of a broader US strategy to prevent American capital and expertise from bolstering China's military and surveillance capabilities.\n\nLooking ahead to late 2025, there is a strong indication that these investment bans could be expanded. A memorandum signed in February 2025, outlining an \"America First Investment Policy,\" signals a continued hardline approach. This policy aims to restrict more Chinese investments into the US and expand prohibitions on US outbound investment into China across a wider range of strategic sectors, including biotechnology, aerospace, advanced manufacturing, and critical infrastructure. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) is expected to play a key role in implementing these enhanced restrictions.\n\n### Hong Kong Fintech Regulation Updates\n\nHong Kong's fintech sector in late 2025 will be operating under an evolving regulatory framework, influenced by both local and mainland Chinese policies. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has been actively implementing new rules that impact companies seeking overseas listings, including in Hong Kong.\n\nThe \"Trial Administrative Measures of Overseas Securities Offering and Listing by Domestic Companies,\" effective since March 2023, remain highly relevant in July 2025. These measures establish a filing-based system for PRC domestic companies listing overseas, covering both direct and indirect listings (including those with Variable Interest Entity, or VIE, structures). The CSRC has expressed support for US and Hong Kong listings by technology-driven companies, provided they offer robust disclosures.\n\nFurthermore, the CSRC's 2025 legislative agenda aims to enhance market stability, transparency, and investor protection. Key areas of focus include new regulations for securities and fund investment consulting, tightened supervision of derivatives trading, and revisions to securities issuance and underwriting rules. These reforms are expected to introduce more standardized rules and clearer governance, impacting financial institutions and corporate entities operating in China's capital markets, which are closely linked to Hong Kong.\n\nSpecific to market operations, new regulations on program trading in China's securities market, issued by the CSRC in May 2024, saw their implementation rules from the Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges take effect in July 2025. Further detailed standards and regulations governing program trading in both securities and futures markets are anticipated throughout 2025, focusing on transparency, reporting requirements, and risk management.\n\nAdditionally, to align with the revised PRC Company Law, the CSRC issued updated \"Guidelines for the Articles of Association of Listed Companies\" and other related rules on March 28, 2025. A-share listed companies are required to adjust their corporate governance structures by January 1, 2026, in response to these changes.\n\nFinally, foreign entities registered to do business in the United States before March 26, 2025, are required to file beneficial ownership information reports with FinCEN by April 25, 2025, under new regulations. This could affect Hong Kong fintech companies with a US (HOOD) demonstrated robust growth in Q3 2025, with its high growth rate primarily driven by core operational improvements and strategic diversification rather than one-time items. The company's revenue doubled year-over-year to a record $1.27 billion, significantly exceeding analyst expectations. Net income surged by 271% to $556 million, and diluted earnings per share increased by 259% to $0.61.\n\n**Drivers of Q3 2025 Earnings Growth:**\n\n*   **Transaction-Based Revenue:** This segment saw a substantial increase of 129% year-over-year, reaching $730 million. This was fueled by strong performance across various trading activities:\n    *   **Cryptocurrencies:** Revenue from cryptocurrencies soared over 300% to $268 million.\n    *   **Equities:** Equities revenue increased by 132% year-over-year to $86 million, with equity notional trading volumes up 126% to a record $647 billion.\n    *   **Options:** Options revenue grew by 50% to $304 million, and options contracts traded increased by 24%.\n*   **Net Interest Revenue:** This segment saw a 66% year-over-year increase, reaching $456 million. This growth was primarily driven by an increase in interest-earning assets and securities lending activity, although partially offset by lower short-term interest rates. Interest-earning assets were up over 50%, propelled by strong margin and cash sweep growth.\n*   **Other Revenues:** This category doubled year-over-year to $88 million, mainly due to an increase in Robinhood Gold subscribers, which reached a record 3.9 million.\n*   **New Product Adoption and Diversification:** Robinhood's \"relentless product velocity\" was highlighted as a key driver.\n    *   **Prediction Markets:** This new offering achieved $100 million in annualized revenue in less than a year, making it Robinhood's fastest-growing business ever. Contract volume more than doubled quarter-over-quarter to 2.3 billion in Q3, with October volumes even higher at 2.5 billion contracts, putting it on track for a $300 million annual run rate.\n    *   **Bitstamp Acquisition:** The acquisition of the global cryptocurrency exchange Bitstamp also contributed significantly, surpassing $100 million in annualized revenue.\n    *   **Robinhood Gold:** The subscription program continued to grow, providing recurring revenue.\n    *   **International Expansion:** Robinhood is expanding its offerings, including tokenized U.S. stocks and ETFs, across 31 EU/EEA countries.\n\n**Growth Sustainability:**\n\nThe growth appears sustainable due to several factors:\n\n*   **Product Diversification:** Robinhood is actively diversifying its offerings beyond traditional trading, with significant traction in prediction markets, index options, and futures.\n*   **Wealth Management Focus:** Bernstein analysts view wealth management as a significant growth driver, noting Robinhood's small share (2.7%) of the large U.S. broking and advisory pool, indicating substantial room for expansion. The Gold program, with its bundled services, is a key part of this strategy.\n*   **Market Share Expansion:** The company is gaining market share in both equities and crypto trading, commanding 30% of U.S. retail crypto trading and 24% of equity options.\n*   **Increased Customer Engagement and Assets:** Funded customers increased by 10% year-over-year to 26.8 million, and total platform assets surged by 119% to $333 billion, driven by continued net deposits and higher valuations.\n*   **Strategic Investments:** Robinhood is investing in product development, international expansion, and new asset classes like tokenized equities.\n\n**Forward-Looking Growth Estimates for 2026:**\n\nAnalysts are optimistic about Robinhood's continued growth into 2026:\n\n*   **Revenue Growth:** Bernstein analysts project Robinhood's revenue to surge from $2.9 billion in 2024 to $6.8 billion by 2026, representing a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of over 51.7%.\n*   **Earnings Growth:** The Zacks Consensus Estimate for Robinhood's 2026 earnings implies year-over-year growth of 16.2%.\n*   **Price Targets:** Wall Street analysts have a bullish consensus with a median price target of $154.50 for HOOD, with some projections as high as $180.00. Mizuho reiterated an Outperform rating and a $172.00 price target, raising its 2026-2027 revenue estimates by 6-7% due to prediction markets growth.\n*   **Diversification Goals:** Robinhood aims to generate over 50% of its revenue from outside the U.S. and from institutional investors within 10 years.\n\nWhile there are some regulatory headwinds concerning prediction markets in certain states, the overall outlook for Robinhood's growth, driven by its diversified operational improvements and strategic initiatives, remains strong for So given stock markets pullback quarter-to-date, what's the recent customer acquisition trend? And what do you expect the customer acquisition cost in Q4? Arthur ChenChief Financial Officer [Foreign Language] For the first question, regarding the asset movement, around 1/3 comes from the net client asset inflow and the remaining 2/3 comes from the market-to-market fluctuations. And in the fourth quarter, quarter-to-date, actually, the mark-to-market implication was negative. But on the flip side, the net asset inflows, we see the momentum remains very robust and there's no any slowdown compared with the second quarter or the third quarter. Then in the third quarter, regarding the client acquisition, the average CAC in the third quarter is around HKD 2,300, slightly up on a Q-on-Q basis. But on the absolute levels, it still [indiscernible] remains our full year's target, the range of HKD 2,500 to HKD 3,000. And in the fourth quarter today, what I witnessed is that both the client acquisition momentum and also client acquisition cost remains quite healthy. So overall speaking, I feel more optimistic regarding our over years client acquisition cost versus our objective in the beginning of this year. Operator Your next question comes from the line of Peter Zhang from JPMorgan. Peter ZhangJPMorgan Chase & Co, Research Division [Foreign Language] This is Peter Zhang from JPMorgan. We have two questions. The first question is related to interest income. We saw the third quarter interest income record a very strong sequential growth. We would like to understand what's the driving forces behind the strong momentum? And can management help us to break down the quarterly interest income into the key items that is the interest income from the client idle cash from margin financing business and from the security lending. And we also noticed that the security borrowings contribution to interest income has been very strong in second and third quarter. We wish to understand is this purely due to the market? Or is there something Futu has been doing at the company level to lead to the strong growth? Our second question is related to crypto business. We wish to understand what's the latest crypto business contribution to your revenue in third quarter? And looking ahead, what will be the driving forces for crypto business to expand? For example, is this mostly due to the expansion of the token offering on your platform? Or do management see other potential business like derivatives or staking business may have some upside to your crypto business? Arthur ChenChief Financial Officer [Foreign Language] Regarding the breakdown of the interest income in the third quarter we have 2 different source arising from the interest income. Number one is from the clients idle cash. The other -- second is from the margin financing and the third is the security borrower and lendings. Actually, in the third quarter, the percentage for these 3 sources are quite even. Regarding the security borrowing and the lending business, we see a very strong momentum in the second quarter and the third quarter, but mainly the driving force was from the market itself. In particular, there will be more utilization for certain hard-to-borrow stocks in the third quarter. Daniel YuanChief of Staff & Head of Investor Relations Peter, this is Daniel. I will take your second question on our crypto business. (FUTU), a leading global tech-driven online brokerage and wealth management platform, announced its unaudited Q2 2025 earnings with US$676.6 million in revenues, up 69.7% year-over-year (\"YoY\"), and US$338.8 million in non-GAAP adjusted net income, up 105.2% YoY.\nAs of June 30, 2025, the Company reported 27.12 million registered users, 5.24 million brokerage accounts and 2.88 million funded accounts. The Company's total client assets surged to US$124 billion, demonstrating an accelerated growth of 17% quarter-over-quarter (\"QoQ\") and 68% YoY. Notably, the Hong Kong market reported strong net inflows, with average client assets increasing QoQ by double digits, while the Singapore market posted robust user growth, with one in every two Singapore residents now a moomoo user [1].\nIn Q2, the Company's total trading volume across its platforms grew by 12% QoQ and 121% YoY to US$457 billion, with US equities hitting US$343 billion, an all-time high. Singaporean, Australian, Japanese, and Canadian equities also recorded historical highs in quarterly trading volume.\nCryptocurrency and AI Lead Product Innovation\nIn the second quarter, cryptocurrency assets grew significantly by 43% QoQ across the Company's platforms. As the Company charts an ambitious course for the future of fintech, it has placed cryptocurrency expansion at the forefront of its business strategy. Following successful launches in Hong Kong and Singapore, the Company has introduced Moomoo Crypto to US investors. It is actively exploring and accelerating the rollout of cryptocurrency trading services across its global markets, aiming to build a one-stop investment platform that seamlessly connects virtual assets with traditional finance.\nAt the same time, the Company is striving to build an end-to-end virtual asset infrastructure lifecycle. Leveraging multiple licenses obtained from regulators of various markets, the Company is set to provide a wide range of services including custody, matching and trading for virtual assets. The Company has launched cryptocurrency deposit and withdrawal services in Hong Kong, and has announced plans to explore offering around-the-clock on-chain tokenized money market fund trading services. In the future, the Company intends to offer more compliant crypto-related features to global investors.\nIn addition to cryptocurrency, Artificial Intelligence (\"AI\") has been in the spotlight as more AI applications emerge in the fintech realm. In Q2, the Company introduced its self-developed blockbuster feature, Moomoo AI, an AI chatbot that empowers users worldwide to make smarter investment decisions with cutting-edge technologies. More advanced tech-driven functions are available in Moomoo Membership, which aims to provide exclusive premium benefits to members and provide value-added services.\nThe Company continues to upgrade its platform features and enrich its product selections to meet various investor demands. In Japan, moomoo further expanded its capabilities in US stock assets by launching US stock options trading. In Malaysia, moomoo introduced IPO financing and earnings calendar features, enhancing the Malaysian stock trading experience. Meanwhile, the Company is improving trading features across various platforms, including launching the Options Strategy Builder feature on mobile and enabling funds and bonds trading on desktop. The recent Bullish IPO attracted strong interest on moomoo US platform, with 100% of moomoo subscribers successfully securing the shares. The moomoo app maintained the top position in Q2 downloads among local stock trading apps in Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Hong Kong [2].","display_source_type":"VECTOR","category":"qu_search","metadata":{"display_source_type":"VECTOR","is_file_result":true,"score":0.7231,"source_type":"vector_store","file_id":"file-UuJVZC9EtxRp4aUtRVLVhw","filename":"10200000099920250820250d81768a4a43645a92e7e77f348bd9.txt","model":"gpt-5-mini"}},"[cite_index=198]":{"source":["10200000099920251118023cdc972f6b9008b6a44507e67e09ad.txt"],"content":"Futu Holdings Limited (FUTU) Q3 2025 Earnings Call November 18, 2025 7:30 AM EST Company Participants Daniel Yuan - Chief of Staff & Head of Investor RelationsLeaf Li - Founder, Chairman & CEOArthur Chen - Chief Financial Officer Conference Call Participants Yun-Yin Wang - China Renaissance, Research DivisionPeter Zhang - JPMorgan Chase & Co, Research DivisionEmma Xu - BofA Securities, Research DivisionYou Fan - China International Capital Corporation Limited, Research DivisionCheng Zhou - UBS Investment Bank, Research DivisionChiyao Huang - Morgan Stanley, Research DivisionLeon QI Presentation Operator Hello, ladies and gentlemen. \"**Futu Holdings Sees Positive Analyst Sentiment Amidst Broader Chinese Economic Concerns in December 2025**\\n\\nDuring the first half of December 2025, Futu Holdings (FUTU) garnered positive attention from Wall Street analysts, with a consensus \\\"Buy\\\" rating and a mean price target suggesting a potential 27.5% upside. This sentiment follows the company's strong third-quarter 2025 financial results, announced on November 18, 2025, which reported significant year-over-year increases in revenues, gross profit, net income, and client assets. While no new earnings reports were released within the December 1-16 timeframe, the Q3 results provided a robust backdrop for investor confidence.\\n\\nInstitutional investors showed mixed activity, with National Bank of Canada FI trimming its stake by 5.1%, while other hedge funds and institutional investors, including LFA Lugano Financial Advisors SA, Hantz Financial Services Inc., Geneos Wealth Management Inc., First Horizon Advisors Inc., and SVB Wealth LLC, either bought new stakes or boosted their existing holdings in Futu during the second quarter of 2025.\\n\\nIn terms of cryptocurrency operations, Futu Securities, a subsidiary of Futu Holdings, received an upgraded Type 1 license in July 2024 from the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) to offer virtual asset dealing services to Hong Kong investors. Furthermore, Futu's subsidiary, Panthertrade, obtained a Virtual Asset Trading Platform License (VATP) in January 2025 and is currently undergoing a second-phase evaluation with the SFC to officially commence operations. Futu also launched zero-commission crypto trading in Hong Kong in August 2024. No new updates on these licenses were reported in early December 2025.\\n\\n**Chinese Brokerage Regulation and Economic Stimulus**\\n\\nChinese regulatory bodies continued to refine market access and trading rules. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) announced a plan on October 27, 2025, to streamline the qualified foreign investor regime. This initiative aims to ease access requirements, enhance operational efficiency, and broaden the investment scope for foreign investors, including allowing them to use exchange-traded fund options for hedging and participate in commodity futures and options trading.\\n\\nRegarding program trading, the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) and Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE) issued new reporting requirements for northbound investors engaged in program trading under the Stock Connect on July 11, 2025. These rules are set to take effect on January 12, 2026, building upon the CSRC's earlier administrative rules and implementation guidelines.\\n\\nIn Hong Kong, the SFC issued a circular on December 12, 2025, concerning clearing and record-keeping rules for over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives, and another on December 5, 2025, for a joint product survey. These updates contribute to the ongoing regulatory framework for financial services in the region, impacting brokers operating in Hong Kong.\\n\\nOn the economic front, China's economy showed mixed signals. While the government plans to issue ultra-long-term special government bonds in 2026 to fund national strategies, security initiatives, equipment upgrades, and consumer goods trade-in programs, recent economic data for November 2025 indicated challenges. Weak retail sales and falling house prices raised doubts about Beijing's 5% GDP growth target for 2025. Despite these concerns, there were prospects of further stimulus measures from Beijing and monetary policy easing to cushion the downside. Official comments from the National Bureau of Statistics on December 15, 2025, reinforced expectations for ongoing targeted stimulus to stabilize growth and address external headwinds and domestic imbalances.\", \"display_source_type\": \"SPECIALIST_TOOL\", \"specialist_name\": \"fundamental\", \"category\": \"specialist_tool\", \"metadata\": {\"is_main_response\": true, \"model\": [\"GeminiWebService\"], \"content\": \"Geopolitical tensions and evolving regulatory landscapes in both the United States and China are poised to significantly impact China ADRs and Hong Kong Fintech in late 2025. Key risks include the ongoing threat of delisting for China ADRs, new and expanded US investment bans, and a series of regulatory updates from China's securities regulator affecting overseas listings and market operations.\\n\\n### China ADR Delisting Risk\\n\\nThe delisting risk for China ADRs, primarily driven by the US Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act (HFCAA), remains a significant concern for late 2025, although immediate threats have been mitigated. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) gained unprecedented access in 2022 to inspect audit firms in mainland China and Hong Kong, which led to the vacating of previous delisting determinations. This access was a crucial step in allowing Chinese companies to remain listed on US exchanges.\\n\\nHowever, the risk has not been entirely eliminated. Some analysts, such as TD Cowen and Goldman Sachs, project a rising probability of delisting in 2025, with estimates ranging from 66% to 70%. This renewed concern is attributed to escalating US-China trade tensions and potential policy shifts under a new US administration. For instance, a potential Trump administration's \\\"America First Investment Policy\\\" could lead to more aggressive delisting actions as part of broader economic decoupling efforts. Companies with dual listings in Hong Kong are generally considered to have lower exposure to delisting risks, as they offer an alternative trading venue for investors.\\n\\n### US-China Investment Bans\\n\\nStringent US investment bans targeting China are already in effect as of January 2025, primarily focusing on sensitive technologies. These restrictions prohibit certain US investments in Chinese companies involved in artificial intelligence (AI), semiconductors, and quantum computing, and require mandatory notifications for other transactions in these sectors. These measures are part of a broader US strategy to prevent American capital and expertise from bolstering China's military and surveillance capabilities.\\n\\nLooking ahead to late 2025, there is a strong indication that these investment bans could be expanded. A memorandum signed in February 2025, outlining an \\\"America First Investment Policy,\\\" signals a continued hardline approach. This policy aims to restrict more Chinese investments into the US and expand prohibitions on US outbound investment into China across a wider range of strategic sectors, including biotechnology, aerospace, advanced manufacturing, and critical infrastructure. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) is expected to play a key role in implementing these enhanced restrictions.\\n\\n### Hong Kong Fintech Regulation Updates\\n\\nHong Kong's fintech sector in late 2025 will be operating under an evolving regulatory framework, influenced by both local and mainland Chinese policies. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has been actively implementing new rules that impact companies seeking overseas listings, including in Hong Kong.\\n\\nThe \\\"Trial Administrative Measures of Overseas Securities Offering and Listing by Domestic Companies,\\\" effective since March 2023, remain highly relevant in July 2025. These measures establish a filing-based system for PRC domestic companies listing overseas, covering both direct and indirect listings (including those with Variable Interest Entity, or VIE, structures). The CSRC has expressed support for US and Hong Kong listings by technology-driven companies, provided they offer robust disclosures.\\n\\nFurthermore, the CSRC's 2025 legislative agenda aims to enhance market stability, transparency, and investor protection. Key areas of focus include new regulations for securities and fund investment consulting, tightened supervision of derivatives trading, and revisions to securities issuance and underwriting rules. These reforms are expected to introduce more standardized rules and clearer governance, impacting financial institutions and corporate entities operating in China's capital markets, which are closely linked to Hong Kong.\\n\\nSpecific to market operations, new regulations on program trading in China's securities market, issued by the CSRC in May 2024, saw their implementation rules from the Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges take effect in July 2025. Further detailed standards and regulations governing program trading in both securities and futures markets are anticipated throughout 2025, focusing on transparency, reporting requirements, and risk management.\\n\\nAdditionally, to align with the revised PRC Company Law, the CSRC issued updated \\\"Guidelines for the Articles of Association of Listed Companies\\\" and other related rules on March 28, 2025. A-share listed companies are required to adjust their corporate governance structures by January 1, 2026, in response to these changes.\\n\\nFinally, foreign entities registered to do business in the United States before March 26, 2025, are required to file beneficial ownership information reports with FinCEN by April 25, 2025, under new regulations. This could affect Hong Kong fintech companies with a US presence.\", \"display_source_type\": \"SPECIALIST_TOOL\", \"specialist_name\": \"fundamental\", \"category\": \"specialist_tool\", [\"GeminiWebService\"], \"content\": \"Robinhood (HOOD) demonstrated robust growth in Q3 2025, with its high growth rate primarily driven by core operational improvements and strategic diversification rather than one-time items. The company's revenue doubled year-over-year to a record $1.27 billion, significantly exceeding analyst expectations. Net income surged by 271% to $556 million, and diluted earnings per share increased by 259% to $0.61.\\n\\n**Drivers of Q3 2025 Earnings Growth:**\\n\\n*   **Transaction-Based Revenue:** This segment saw a substantial increase of 129% year-over-year, reaching $730 million. This was fueled by strong performance across various trading activities:\\n    *   **Cryptocurrencies:** Revenue from cryptocurrencies soared over 300% to $268 million.\\n    *   **Equities:** Equities revenue increased by 132% year-over-year to $86 million, with equity notional trading volumes up 126% to a record $647 billion.\\n    *   **Options:** Options revenue grew by 50% to $304 million, and options contracts traded increased by 24%.\\n*   **Net Interest Revenue:** This segment saw a 66% year-over-year increase, reaching $456 million. This growth was primarily driven by an increase in interest-earning assets and securities lending activity, although partially offset by lower short-term interest rates. Interest-earning assets were up over 50%, propelled by strong margin and cash sweep growth.\\n*   **Other Revenues:** This category doubled year-over-year to $88 million, mainly due to an increase in Robinhood Gold subscribers, which reached a record 3.9 million.\\n*   **New Product Adoption and Diversification:** Robinhood's \\\"relentless product velocity\\\" was highlighted as a key driver.\\n    *   **Prediction Markets:** This new offering achieved $100 million in annualized revenue in less than a year, making it Robinhood's fastest-growing business ever. Contract volume more than doubled quarter-over-quarter to 2.3 billion in Q3, with October volumes even higher at 2.5 billion contracts, putting it on track for a $300 million annual run rate.\\n    *   **Bitstamp Acquisition:** The acquisition of the global cryptocurrency exchange Bitstamp also contributed significantly, surpassing $100 million in annualized revenue.\\n    *   **Robinhood Gold:** The subscription program continued to grow, providing recurring revenue.\\n    *   **International Expansion:** Robinhood is expanding its offerings, including tokenized U.S. stocks and ETFs, across 31 EU/EEA countries.\\n\\n**Growth Sustainability:**\\n\\nThe growth appears sustainable due to several factors:\\n\\n*   **Product Diversification:** Robinhood is actively diversifying its offerings beyond traditional trading, with significant traction in prediction markets, index options, and futures.\\n*   **Wealth Management Focus:** Bernstein analysts view wealth management as a significant growth driver, noting Robinhood's small share (2.7%) of the large U.S. broking and advisory pool, indicating substantial room for expansion. The Gold program, with its bundled services, is a key part of this strategy.\\n*   **Market Share Expansion:** The company is gaining market share in both equities and crypto trading, commanding 30% of U.S. retail crypto trading and 24% of equity options.\\n*   **Increased Customer Engagement and Assets:** Funded customers increased by 10% year-over-year to 26.8 million, and total platform assets surged by 119% to $333 billion, driven by continued net deposits and higher valuations.\\n*   **Strategic Investments:** Robinhood is investing in product development, international expansion, and new asset classes like tokenized equities.\\n\\n**Forward-Looking Growth Estimates for 2026:**\\n\\nAnalysts are optimistic about Robinhood's continued growth into 2026:\\n\\n*   **Revenue Growth:** Bernstein analysts project Robinhood's revenue to surge from $2.9 billion in 2024 to $6.8 billion by 2026, representing a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of over 51.7%.\\n*   **Earnings Growth:** The Zacks Consensus Estimate for Robinhood's 2026 earnings implies year-over-year growth of 16.2%.\\n*   **Price Targets:** Wall Street analysts have a bullish consensus with a median price target of $154.50 for HOOD, with some projections as high as $180.00. Mizuho reiterated an Outperform rating and a $172.00 price target, raising its 2026-2027 revenue estimates by 6-7% due to prediction markets growth.\\n*   **Diversification Goals:** Robinhood aims to generate over 50% of its revenue from outside the U.S. and from institutional investors within 10 years.\\n\\nWhile there are some regulatory headwinds concerning prediction markets in certain states, the overall outlook for Robinhood's growth, driven by its diversified operational improvements and strategic initiatives, remains strong for 2026.\", \"display_source_type\": \"SPECIALIST_TOOL\", So given stock markets pullback quarter-to-date, what's the recent customer acquisition trend? And what do you expect the customer acquisition cost in Q4? Arthur ChenChief Financial Officer [Foreign Language] For the first question, regarding the asset movement, around 1/3 comes from the net client asset inflow and the remaining 2/3 comes from the market-to-market fluctuations. And in the fourth quarter, quarter-to-date, actually, the mark-to-market implication was negative. But on the flip side, the net asset inflows, we see the momentum remains very robust and there's no any slowdown compared with the second quarter or the third quarter. Then in the third quarter, regarding the client acquisition, the average CAC in the third quarter is around HKD 2,300, slightly up on a Q-on-Q basis. But on the absolute levels, it still [indiscernible] remains our full year's target, the range of HKD 2,500 to HKD 3,000. And in the fourth quarter today, what I witnessed is that both the client acquisition momentum and also client acquisition cost remains quite healthy. So overall speaking, I feel more optimistic regarding our over years client acquisition cost versus our objective in the beginning of this year. Operator Your next question comes from the line of Peter Zhang from JPMorgan. Peter ZhangJPMorgan Chase & Co, Research Division [Foreign Language] This is Peter Zhang from JPMorgan. We have two questions. The first question is related to interest income. We saw the third quarter interest income record a very strong sequential growth. We would like to understand what's the driving forces behind the strong momentum? And can management help us to break down the quarterly interest income into the key items that is the interest income from the client idle cash from margin financing business and from the security lending. And we also noticed that the security borrowings contribution to interest income has been very strong in second and third quarter. We wish to understand is this purely due to the market? Or is there something Futu has been doing at the company level to lead to the strong growth? Our second question is related to crypto business. Arthur ChenChief Financial Officer [Foreign Language] Regarding the breakdown of the interest income in the third quarter we have 2 different source arising from the interest income. Number one is from the clients idle cash. The other -- second is from the margin financing and the third is the security borrower and lendings. Actually, in the third quarter, the percentage for these 3 sources are quite even. Regarding the security borrowing and the lending business, we see a very strong momentum in the second quarter and the third quarter, but mainly the driving force was from the market itself. I will take your second question on our crypto business. So the strong crypto growth was quite broad-based across the 3 markets that we currently offer crypto trading.\", \"display_source_type\": \"VECTOR\", \"category\": \"qu_search\", \"metadata\": {\"display_source_type\": \"VECTOR\", \"is_file_result\": true, \"score\": 0.7361, \"source_type\": \"vector_store\", \"file_id\": \"file-N2nsZgATMDkbeX4dLsLucb\", \"filename\": \"10200000099920251118023cdc972f6b9008b6a44507e67e09ad.txt\", \"model\": \"gpt-5-mini\"}}, \"[cite_index=197]\": {\"source\": [\"10200000099920250820250d81768a4a43645a92e7e77f348bd9.txt\"], \"content\": \"JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 20, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- Moomoo's parent company Futu Holdings Ltd. (FUTU), a leading global tech-driven online brokerage and wealth management platform, announced its unaudited Q2 2025 earnings with US$676.6 million in revenues, up 69.7% year-over-year (\\\"YoY\\\"), and US$338.8 million in non-GAAP adjusted net income, up 105.2% YoY.\\nAs of June 30, 2025, the Company reported 27.12 million registered users, 5.24 million brokerage accounts and 2.88 million funded accounts. The Company's total client assets surged to US$124 billion, demonstrating an accelerated growth of 17% quarter-over-quarter (\\\"QoQ\\\") and 68% YoY. Notably, the Hong Kong market reported strong net inflows, with average client assets increasing QoQ by double digits, while the Singapore market posted robust user growth, with one in every two Singapore residents now a moomoo user [1].\\nIn Q2, the Company's total trading volume across its platforms grew by 12% QoQ and 121% YoY to US$457 billion, with US equities hitting US$343 billion, an all-time high. Singaporean, Australian, Japanese, and Canadian equities also recorded historical highs in quarterly trading volume.\\nCryptocurrency and AI Lead Product Innovation\\nIn the second quarter, cryptocurrency assets grew significantly by 43% QoQ across the Company's platforms. As the Company charts an ambitious course for the future of fintech, it has placed cryptocurrency expansion at the forefront of its business strategy. Following successful launches in Hong Kong and Singapore, the Company has introduced Moomoo Crypto to US investors. It is actively exploring and accelerating the rollout of cryptocurrency trading services across its global markets, aiming to build a one-stop investment platform that seamlessly connects virtual assets with traditional finance.\\nAt the same time, the Company is striving to build an end-to-end virtual asset infrastructure lifecycle. Leveraging multiple licenses obtained from regulators of various markets, the Company is set to provide a wide range of services including custody, matching and trading for virtual assets. The Company has launched cryptocurrency deposit and withdrawal services in Hong Kong, and has announced plans to explore offering around-the-clock on-chain tokenized money market fund trading services. In the future, the Company intends to offer more compliant crypto-related features to global investors.\\nIn addition to cryptocurrency, Artificial Intelligence (\\\"AI\\\") has been in the spotlight as more AI applications emerge in the fintech realm. In Q2, the Company introduced its self-developed blockbuster feature, Moomoo AI, an AI chatbot that empowers users worldwide to make smarter investment decisions with cutting-edge technologies. December itself has a mixed history for Bitcoin, with an average gain of just 4.6% over the past decade. Result from x.com","url":"https://x.com/Tesla/status/1999628353809354898","display_source_type":"X.AI_GROK_X"}},"[cite_index=93]":{"source":["GeminiWebService"],"content":"**Futu Holdings Sees Positive Analyst Sentiment Amidst Broader Chinese Economic Concerns in December 2025**\n\nDuring the first half of December 2025, Futu Holdings (FUTU) garnered positive attention from Wall Street analysts, with a consensus \"Buy\" rating and a mean price target suggesting a potential 27.5% upside. This sentiment follows the company's strong third-quarter 2025 financial results, announced on November 18, 2025, which reported significant year-over-year increases in revenues, gross profit, net income, and client assets. While no new earnings reports were released within the December 1-16 timeframe, the Q3 results provided a robust backdrop for investor confidence.\n\nInstitutional investors showed mixed activity, with National Bank of Canada FI trimming its stake by 5.1%, while other hedge funds and institutional investors, including LFA Lugano Financial Advisors SA, Hantz Financial Services Inc., Geneos Wealth Management Inc., First Horizon Advisors Inc., and SVB Wealth LLC, either bought new stakes or boosted their existing holdings in Futu during the second quarter of 2025.\n\nIn terms of cryptocurrency operations, Futu Securities, a subsidiary of Futu Holdings, received an upgraded Type 1 license in July 2024 from the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) to offer virtual asset dealing services to Hong Kong investors. Furthermore, Futu's subsidiary, Panthertrade, obtained a Virtual Asset Trading Platform License (VATP) in January 2025 and is currently undergoing a second-phase evaluation with the SFC to officially commence operations. Futu also launched zero-commission crypto trading in Hong Kong in August 2024. No new updates on these licenses were reported in early December 2025.\n\n**Chinese Brokerage Regulation and Economic Stimulus**\n\nChinese regulatory bodies continued to refine market access and trading rules. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) announced a plan on October 27, 2025, to streamline the qualified foreign investor regime. This initiative aims to ease access requirements, enhance operational efficiency, and broaden the investment scope for foreign investors, including allowing them to use exchange-traded fund options for hedging and participate in commodity futures and options trading.\n\nRegarding program trading, the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) and Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE) issued new reporting requirements for northbound investors engaged in program trading under the Stock Connect on July 11, 2025. These rules are set to take effect on January 12, 2026, building upon the CSRC's earlier administrative rules and implementation guidelines.\n\nIn Hong Kong, the SFC issued a circular on December 12, 2025, concerning clearing and record-keeping rules for over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives, and another on December 5, 2025, for a joint product survey. These updates contribute to the ongoing regulatory framework for financial services in the region, impacting brokers operating in Hong Kong.\n\nOn the economic front, China's economy showed mixed signals. While the government plans to issue ultra-long-term special government bonds in 2026 to fund national strategies, security initiatives, equipment upgrades, and consumer goods trade-in programs, recent economic data for November 2025 indicated challenges. Weak retail sales and falling house prices raised doubts about Beijing's 5% GDP growth target for 2025. Despite these concerns, there were prospects of further stimulus measures from Beijing and monetary policy easing to cushion the downside. Official comments from the National Bureau of Statistics on December 15, 2025, reinforced expectations for ongoing targeted stimulus to stabilize growth and address external headwinds and domestic tensions and evolving regulatory landscapes in both the United States and China are poised to significantly impact China ADRs and Hong Kong Fintech in late 2025. Key risks include the ongoing threat of delisting for China ADRs, new and expanded US investment bans, and a series of regulatory updates from China's securities regulator affecting overseas listings and market operations.\n\n### China ADR Delisting Risk\n\nThe delisting risk for China ADRs, primarily driven by the US Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act (HFCAA), remains a significant concern for late 2025, although immediate threats have been mitigated. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) gained unprecedented access in 2022 to inspect audit firms in mainland China and Hong Kong, which led to the vacating of previous delisting determinations. This access was a crucial step in allowing Chinese companies to remain listed on US exchanges.\n\nHowever, the risk has not been entirely eliminated. Some analysts, such as TD Cowen and Goldman Sachs, project a rising probability of delisting in 2025, with estimates ranging from 66% to 70%. This renewed concern is attributed to escalating US-China trade tensions and potential policy shifts under a new US administration. For instance, a potential Trump administration's \"America First Investment Policy\" could lead to more aggressive delisting actions as part of broader economic decoupling efforts. Companies with dual listings in Hong Kong are generally considered to have lower exposure to delisting risks, as they offer an alternative trading venue for investors.\n\n### US-China Investment Bans\n\nStringent US investment bans targeting China are already in effect as of January 2025, primarily focusing on sensitive technologies. These restrictions prohibit certain US investments in Chinese companies involved in artificial intelligence (AI), semiconductors, and quantum computing, and require mandatory notifications for other transactions in these sectors. These measures are part of a broader US strategy to prevent American capital and expertise from bolstering China's military and surveillance capabilities.\n\nLooking ahead to late 2025, there is a strong indication that these investment bans could be expanded. A memorandum signed in February 2025, outlining an \"America First Investment Policy,\" signals a continued hardline approach. This policy aims to restrict more Chinese investments into the US and expand prohibitions on US outbound investment into China across a wider range of strategic sectors, including biotechnology, aerospace, advanced manufacturing, and critical infrastructure. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) is expected to play a key role in implementing these enhanced restrictions.\n\n### Hong Kong Fintech Regulation Updates\n\nHong Kong's fintech sector in late 2025 will be operating under an evolving regulatory framework, influenced by both local and mainland Chinese policies. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has been actively implementing new rules that impact companies seeking overseas listings, including in Hong Kong.\n\nThe \"Trial Administrative Measures of Overseas Securities Offering and Listing by Domestic Companies,\" effective since March 2023, remain highly relevant in July 2025. These measures establish a filing-based system for PRC domestic companies listing overseas, covering both direct and indirect listings (including those with Variable Interest Entity, or VIE, structures). The CSRC has expressed support for US and Hong Kong listings by technology-driven companies, provided they offer robust disclosures.\n\nFurthermore, the CSRC's 2025 legislative agenda aims to enhance market stability, transparency, and investor protection. Key areas of focus include new regulations for securities and fund investment consulting, tightened supervision of derivatives trading, and revisions to securities issuance and underwriting rules. These reforms are expected to introduce more standardized rules and clearer governance, impacting financial institutions and corporate entities operating in China's capital markets, which are closely linked to Hong Kong.\n\nSpecific to market operations, new regulations on program trading in China's securities market, issued by the CSRC in May 2024, saw their implementation rules from the Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges take effect in July 2025. Further detailed standards and regulations governing program trading in both securities and futures markets are anticipated throughout 2025, focusing on transparency, reporting requirements, and risk management.\n\nAdditionally, to align with the revised PRC Company Law, the CSRC issued updated \"Guidelines for the Articles of Association of Listed Companies\" and other related rules on March 28, 2025. A-share listed companies are required to adjust their corporate governance structures by January 1, 2026, in response to these changes.\n\nFinally, foreign entities registered to do business in the United States before March 26, 2025, are required to file beneficial ownership information reports with FinCEN by April 25, 2025, under new regulations. This could affect Hong Kong fintech companies with a US (HOOD) demonstrated robust growth in Q3 2025, with its high growth rate primarily driven by core operational improvements and strategic diversification rather than one-time items. The company's revenue doubled year-over-year to a record $1.27 billion, significantly exceeding analyst expectations. Net income surged by 271% to $556 million, and diluted earnings per share increased by 259% to $0.61.\n\n**Drivers of Q3 2025 Earnings Growth:**\n\n*   **Transaction-Based Revenue:** This segment saw a substantial increase of 129% year-over-year, reaching $730 million. This was fueled by strong performance across various trading activities:\n    *   **Cryptocurrencies:** Revenue from cryptocurrencies soared over 300% to $268 million.\n    *   **Equities:** Equities revenue increased by 132% year-over-year to $86 million, with equity notional trading volumes up 126% to a record $647 billion.\n    *   **Options:** Options revenue grew by 50% to $304 million, and options contracts traded increased by 24%.\n*   **Net Interest Revenue:** This segment saw a 66% year-over-year increase, reaching $456 million. This growth was primarily driven by an increase in interest-earning assets and securities lending activity, although partially offset by lower short-term interest rates. Interest-earning assets were up over 50%, propelled by strong margin and cash sweep growth.\n*   **Other Revenues:** This category doubled year-over-year to $88 million, mainly due to an increase in Robinhood Gold subscribers, which reached a record 3.9 million.\n*   **New Product Adoption and Diversification:** Robinhood's \"relentless product velocity\" was highlighted as a key driver.\n    *   **Prediction Markets:** This new offering achieved $100 million in annualized revenue in less than a year, making it Robinhood's fastest-growing business ever. Contract volume more than doubled quarter-over-quarter to 2.3 billion in Q3, with October volumes even higher at 2.5 billion contracts, putting it on track for a $300 million annual run rate.\n    *   **Bitstamp Acquisition:** The acquisition of the global cryptocurrency exchange Bitstamp also contributed significantly, surpassing $100 million in annualized revenue.\n    *   **Robinhood Gold:** The subscription program continued to grow, providing recurring revenue.\n    *   **International Expansion:** Robinhood is expanding its offerings, including tokenized U.S. stocks and ETFs, across 31 EU/EEA countries.\n\n**Growth Sustainability:**\n\nThe growth appears sustainable due to several factors:\n\n*   **Product Diversification:** Robinhood is actively diversifying its offerings beyond traditional trading, with significant traction in prediction markets, index options, and futures.\n*   **Wealth Management Focus:** Bernstein analysts view wealth management as a significant growth driver, noting Robinhood's small share (2.7%) of the large U.S. broking and advisory pool, indicating substantial room for expansion. The Gold program, with its bundled services, is a key part of this strategy.\n*   **Market Share Expansion:** The company is gaining market share in both equities and crypto trading, commanding 30% of U.S. retail crypto trading and 24% of equity options.\n*   **Increased Customer Engagement and Assets:** Funded customers increased by 10% year-over-year to 26.8 million, and total platform assets surged by 119% to $333 billion, driven by continued net deposits and higher valuations.\n*   **Strategic Investments:** Robinhood is investing in product development, international expansion, and new asset classes like tokenized equities.\n\n**Forward-Looking Growth Estimates for 2026:**\n\nAnalysts are optimistic about Robinhood's continued growth into 2026:\n\n*   **Revenue Growth:** Bernstein analysts project Robinhood's revenue to surge from $2.9 billion in 2024 to $6.8 billion by 2026, representing a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of over 51.7%.\n*   **Earnings Growth:** The Zacks Consensus Estimate for Robinhood's 2026 earnings implies year-over-year growth of 16.2%.\n*   **Price Targets:** Wall Street analysts have a bullish consensus with a median price target of $154.50 for HOOD, with some projections as high as $180.00. Mizuho reiterated an Outperform rating and a $172.00 price target, raising its 2026-2027 revenue estimates by 6-7% due to prediction markets growth.\n*   **Diversification Goals:** Robinhood aims to generate over 50% of its revenue from outside the U.S. and from institutional investors within 10 years.\n\nWhile there are some regulatory headwinds concerning prediction markets in certain states, the overall outlook for Robinhood's growth, driven by its diversified operational improvements and strategic initiatives, remains strong for Arthur ChenChief Financial Officer [Foreign Language] For the first question, regarding the asset movement, around 1/3 comes from the net client asset inflow and the remaining 2/3 comes from the market-to-market fluctuations. And in the fourth quarter, quarter-to-date, actually, the mark-to-market implication was negative. But on the flip side, the net asset inflows, we see the momentum remains very robust and there's no any slowdown compared with the second quarter or the third quarter. Then in the third quarter, regarding the client acquisition, the average CAC in the third quarter is around HKD 2,300, slightly up on a Q-on-Q basis. But on the absolute levels, it still [indiscernible] remains our full year's target, the range of HKD 2,500 to HKD 3,000. And in the fourth quarter today, what I witnessed is that both the client acquisition momentum and also client acquisition cost remains quite healthy. (FUTU), a leading global tech-driven online brokerage and wealth management platform, announced its unaudited Q2 2025 earnings with US$676.6 million in revenues, up 69.7% year-over-year (\"YoY\"), and US$338.8 million in non-GAAP adjusted net income, up 105.2% YoY.\nAs of June 30, 2025, the Company reported 27.12 million registered users, 5.24 million brokerage accounts and 2.88 million funded accounts. The Company's total client assets surged to US$124 billion, demonstrating an accelerated growth of 17% quarter-over-quarter (\"QoQ\") and 68% YoY. Notably, the Hong Kong market reported strong net inflows, with average client assets increasing QoQ by double digits, while the Singapore market posted robust user growth, with one in every two Singapore residents now a moomoo user [1].\nIn Q2, the Company's total trading volume across its platforms grew by 12% QoQ and 121% YoY to US$457 billion, with US equities hitting US$343 billion, an all-time high. Singaporean, Australian, Japanese, and Canadian equities also recorded historical highs in quarterly trading volume.\nCryptocurrency and AI Lead Product Innovation\nIn the second quarter, cryptocurrency assets grew significantly by 43% QoQ across the Company's platforms. As the Company charts an ambitious course for the future of fintech, it has placed cryptocurrency expansion at the forefront of its business strategy. Following successful launches in Hong Kong and Singapore, the Company has introduced Moomoo Crypto to US investors. It is actively exploring and accelerating the rollout of cryptocurrency trading services across its global markets, aiming to build a one-stop investment platform that seamlessly connects virtual assets with traditional finance.\nAt the same time, the Company is striving to build an end-to-end virtual asset infrastructure lifecycle. Leveraging multiple licenses obtained from regulators of various markets, the Company is set to provide a wide range of services including custody, matching and trading for virtual assets. The Company has launched cryptocurrency deposit and withdrawal services in Hong Kong, and has announced plans to explore offering around-the-clock on-chain tokenized money market fund trading services. In the future, the Company intends to offer more compliant crypto-related features to global investors.\nIn addition to cryptocurrency, Artificial Intelligence (\"AI\") has been in the spotlight as more AI applications emerge in the fintech realm. In Q2, the Company introduced its self-developed blockbuster feature, Moomoo AI, an AI chatbot that empowers users worldwide to make smarter investment decisions with cutting-edge technologies. More advanced tech-driven functions are available in Moomoo Membership, which aims to provide exclusive premium benefits to members and provide value-added services.\nThe Company continues to upgrade its platform features and enrich its product selections to meet various investor demands. In Japan, moomoo further expanded its capabilities in US stock assets by launching US stock options trading. In Malaysia, moomoo introduced IPO financing and earnings calendar features, enhancing the Malaysian stock trading experience. Meanwhile, the Company is improving trading features across various platforms, including launching the Options Strategy Builder feature on mobile and enabling funds and bonds trading on desktop. The recent Bullish IPO attracted strong interest on moomoo US platform, with 100% of moomoo subscribers successfully securing the shares. The moomoo app maintained the top position in Q2 downloads among local stock trading apps in Australia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Hong Kong [2].","display_source_type":"VECTOR","category":"qu_search","metadata":{"display_source_type":"VECTOR","is_file_result":true,"score":0.7231,"source_type":"vector_store","file_id":"file-UuJVZC9EtxRp4aUtRVLVhw","filename":"10200000099920250820250d81768a4a43645a92e7e77f348bd9.txt","model":"gpt-5-mini"}},"[cite_index=198]":{"source":["10200000099920251118023cdc972f6b9008b6a44507e67e09ad.txt"],"content":"Futu Holdings Limited (FUTU) Q3 2025 Earnings Call November 18, 2025 7:30 AM EST Company Participants Daniel Yuan - Chief of Staff & Head of Investor RelationsLeaf Li - Founder, Chairman & CEOArthur Chen - Chief Financial Officer Conference Call Participants Yun-Yin Wang - China Renaissance, Research DivisionPeter Zhang - JPMorgan Chase & Co, Research DivisionEmma Xu - BofA Securities, Research DivisionYou Fan - China International Capital Corporation Limited, Research DivisionCheng Zhou - UBS Investment Bank, Research DivisionChiyao Huang - Morgan Stanley, Research DivisionLeon QI Presentation Operator Hello, ladies and gentlemen. Leaf LiFounder, Chairman & CEO [Foreign Language] Daniel YuanChief of Staff & Head of Investor Relations [Interpreted] In the third quarter, Hong Kong posted the highest quarterly net client adds since the first quarter of 2021 and remained the largest contributor to new funded accounts among all markets for 4 straight quarters. 美元，上漲 +2.22%單日高點：197.35 美元，距離歷史新高 199.54 僅一步之遙成交量：2146.2 萬股，交投活絡市值：271.3 億美元，金融科技板塊的重要代表從技術面來看，富途股價自 2023 年低點 27.35 美元 起漲，至今已累積逾 600% 漲幅。今年以來沿著 20 週均線穩步推進，突破 190 美元壓力位後，市場情緒持續偏多。---上漲動能解析1. 用戶增長穩健富途憑藉「moomoo」交易平台，持續拓展香港、新加坡與美國市場，用戶數與資產規模齊步上揚。高淨值及新世代投資人雙重驅動，形成穩定的流量入口。2. 業績優於預期最新財報顯示營收與淨利皆超市場預期，佣金與利息收入穩定成長。增值服務（如 IPO 配售、理財產品）貢獻逐漸提升。3. 監管環境改善近期中國與香港對跨境券商的監管態度相對寬鬆，市場對政策風險的擔憂有所緩解。---技術面觀察壓力位：197.5 ~ 200 美元，若能放量突破，將刷新歷史高點。支撐位：185 美元區間，短線回檔不破此位，趨勢仍屬健康。量價關係：放量上漲，籌碼集中，顯示多頭控盤力強。---專家觀點富途已經不是單純的「港股券商」，而是成長為具備 全球科技金融平台屬性 analysts, with a consensus \"Buy\" rating and a mean price target suggesting a potential 27.5% upside. This sentiment follows the company's strong third-quarter 2025 financial results, announced on November 18, 2025, which reported significant year-over-year increases in revenues, gross profit, net income, and client assets. While no new earnings reports were released within the December 1-16 timeframe, the Q3 results provided a robust backdrop for investor confidence.\n\nInstitutional investors showed mixed activity, with National Bank of Canada FI trimming its stake by 5.1%, while other hedge funds and institutional investors, including LFA Lugano Financial Advisors SA, Hantz Financial Services Inc., Geneos Wealth Management Inc., First Horizon Advisors Inc., and SVB Wealth LLC, either bought new stakes or boosted their existing holdings in Futu during the second quarter of 2025.\n\nIn terms of cryptocurrency operations, Futu Securities, a subsidiary of Futu Holdings, received an upgraded Type 1 license in July 2024 from the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) to offer virtual asset dealing services to Hong Kong investors. Furthermore, Futu's subsidiary, Panthertrade, obtained a Virtual Asset Trading Platform License (VATP) in January 2025 and is currently undergoing a second-phase evaluation with the SFC to officially commence operations. Futu also launched zero-commission crypto trading in Hong Kong in August 2024. No new updates on these licenses were reported in early December 2025.\n\n**Chinese Brokerage Regulation and Economic Stimulus**\n\nChinese regulatory bodies continued to refine market access and trading rules. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) announced a plan on October 27, 2025, to streamline the qualified foreign investor regime. This initiative aims to ease access requirements, enhance operational efficiency, and broaden the investment scope for foreign investors, including allowing them to use exchange-traded fund options for hedging and participate in commodity futures and options trading.\n\nRegarding program trading, the Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) and Shenzhen Stock Exchange (SZSE) issued new reporting requirements for northbound investors engaged in program trading under the Stock Connect on July 11, 2025. These rules are set to take effect on January 12, 2026, building upon the CSRC's earlier administrative rules and implementation guidelines.\n\nIn Hong Kong, the SFC issued a circular on December 12, 2025, concerning clearing and record-keeping rules for over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives, and another on December 5, 2025, for a joint product survey. These updates contribute to the ongoing regulatory framework for financial services in the region, impacting brokers operating in Hong Kong.\n\nOn the economic front, China's economy showed mixed signals. While the government plans to issue ultra-long-term special government bonds in 2026 to fund national strategies, security initiatives, equipment upgrades, and consumer goods trade-in programs, recent economic data for November 2025 indicated challenges. Weak retail sales and falling house prices raised doubts about Beijing's 5% GDP growth target for 2025. Despite these concerns, there were prospects of further stimulus measures from Beijing and monetary policy easing to cushion the downside. Official comments from the National Bureau of Statistics on December 15, 2025, reinforced expectations for ongoing targeted stimulus to stabilize growth and address external headwinds and domestic tensions and evolving regulatory landscapes in both the United States and China are poised to significantly impact China ADRs and Hong Kong Fintech in late 2025. Key risks include the ongoing threat of delisting for China ADRs, new and expanded US investment bans, and a series of regulatory updates from China's securities regulator affecting overseas listings and market operations.\n\n### China ADR Delisting Risk\n\nThe delisting risk for China ADRs, primarily driven by the US Holding Foreign Companies Accountable Act (HFCAA), remains a significant concern for late 2025, although immediate threats have been mitigated. The Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (PCAOB) gained unprecedented access in 2022 to inspect audit firms in mainland China and Hong Kong, which led to the vacating of previous delisting determinations. This access was a crucial step in allowing Chinese companies to remain listed on US exchanges.\n\nHowever, the risk has not been entirely eliminated. Some analysts, such as TD Cowen and Goldman Sachs, project a rising probability of delisting in 2025, with estimates ranging from 66% to 70%. This renewed concern is attributed to escalating US-China trade tensions and potential policy shifts under a new US administration. For instance, a potential Trump administration's \"America First Investment Policy\" could lead to more aggressive delisting actions as part of broader economic decoupling efforts. Companies with dual listings in Hong Kong are generally considered to have lower exposure to delisting risks, as they offer an alternative trading venue for investors.\n\n### US-China Investment Bans\n\nStringent US investment bans targeting China are already in effect as of January 2025, primarily focusing on sensitive technologies. These restrictions prohibit certain US investments in Chinese companies involved in artificial intelligence (AI), semiconductors, and quantum computing, and require mandatory notifications for other transactions in these sectors. These measures are part of a broader US strategy to prevent American capital and expertise from bolstering China's military and surveillance capabilities.\n\nLooking ahead to late 2025, there is a strong indication that these investment bans could be expanded. A memorandum signed in February 2025, outlining an \"America First Investment Policy,\" signals a continued hardline approach. This policy aims to restrict more Chinese investments into the US and expand prohibitions on US outbound investment into China across a wider range of strategic sectors, including biotechnology, aerospace, advanced manufacturing, and critical infrastructure. The Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) is expected to play a key role in implementing these enhanced restrictions.\n\n### Hong Kong Fintech Regulation Updates\n\nHong Kong's fintech sector in late 2025 will be operating under an evolving regulatory framework, influenced by both local and mainland Chinese policies. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has been actively implementing new rules that impact companies seeking overseas listings, including in Hong Kong.\n\nThe \"Trial Administrative Measures of Overseas Securities Offering and Listing by Domestic Companies,\" effective since March 2023, remain highly relevant in July 2025. These measures establish a filing-based system for PRC domestic companies listing overseas, covering both direct and indirect listings (including those with Variable Interest Entity, or VIE, structures). The CSRC has expressed support for US and Hong Kong listings by technology-driven companies, provided they offer robust disclosures.\n\nFurthermore, the CSRC's 2025 legislative agenda aims to enhance market stability, transparency, and investor protection. Key areas of focus include new regulations for securities and fund investment consulting, tightened supervision of derivatives trading, and revisions to securities issuance and underwriting rules. These reforms are expected to introduce more standardized rules and clearer governance, impacting financial institutions and corporate entities operating in China's capital markets, which are closely linked to Hong Kong.\n\nSpecific to market operations, new regulations on program trading in China's securities market, issued by the CSRC in May 2024, saw their implementation rules from the Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges take effect in July 2025. Further detailed standards and regulations governing program trading in both securities and futures markets are anticipated throughout 2025, focusing on transparency, reporting requirements, and risk management.\n\nAdditionally, to align with the revised PRC Company Law, the CSRC issued updated \"Guidelines for the Articles of Association of Listed Companies\" and other related rules on March 28, 2025. A-share listed companies are required to adjust their corporate governance structures by January 1, 2026, in response to these changes.\n\nFinally, foreign entities registered to do business in the United States before March 26, 2025, are required to file beneficial ownership information reports with FinCEN by April 25, 2025, under new regulations. This could affect Hong Kong fintech companies with a US (HOOD) demonstrated robust growth in Q3 2025, with its high growth rate primarily driven by core operational improvements and strategic diversification rather than one-time items. The company's revenue doubled year-over-year to a record $1.27 billion, significantly exceeding analyst expectations. Net income surged by 271% to $556 million, and diluted earnings per share increased by 259% to $0.61.\n\n**Drivers of Q3 2025 Earnings Growth:**\n\n*   **Transaction-Based Revenue:** This segment saw a substantial increase of 129% year-over-year, reaching $730 million. This was fueled by strong performance across various trading activities:\n    *   **Cryptocurrencies:** Revenue from cryptocurrencies soared over 300% to $268 million.\n    *   **Equities:** Equities revenue increased by 132% year-over-year to $86 million, with equity notional trading volumes up 126% to a record $647 billion.\n    *   **Options:** Options revenue grew by 50% to $304 million, and options contracts traded increased by 24%.\n*   **Net Interest Revenue:** This segment saw a 66% year-over-year increase, reaching $456 million. This growth was primarily driven by an increase in interest-earning assets and securities lending activity, although partially offset by lower short-term interest rates. Interest-earning assets were up over 50%, propelled by strong margin and cash sweep growth.\n*   **Other Revenues:** This category doubled year-over-year to $88 million, mainly due to an increase in Robinhood Gold subscribers, which reached a record 3.9 million.\n*   **New Product Adoption and Diversification:** Robinhood's \"relentless product velocity\" was highlighted as a key driver.\n    *   **Prediction Markets:** This new offering achieved $100 million in annualized revenue in less than a year, making it Robinhood's fastest-growing business ever. Contract volume more than doubled quarter-over-quarter to 2.3 billion in Q3, with October volumes even higher at 2.5 billion contracts, putting it on track for a $300 million annual run rate.\n    *   **Bitstamp Acquisition:** The acquisition of the global cryptocurrency exchange Bitstamp also contributed significantly, surpassing $100 million in annualized revenue.\n    *   **Robinhood Gold:** The subscription program continued to grow, providing recurring revenue.\n    *   **International Expansion:** Robinhood is expanding its offerings, including tokenized U.S. stocks and ETFs, across 31 EU/EEA countries.\n\n**Growth Sustainability:**\n\nThe growth appears sustainable due to several factors:\n\n*   **Product Diversification:** Robinhood is actively diversifying its offerings beyond traditional trading, with significant traction in prediction markets, index options, and futures.\n*   **Wealth Management Focus:** Bernstein analysts view wealth management as a significant growth driver, noting Robinhood's small share (2.7%) of the large U.S. broking and advisory pool, indicating substantial room for expansion. The Gold program, with its bundled services, is a key part of this strategy.\n*   **Market Share Expansion:** The company is gaining market share in both equities and crypto trading, commanding 30% of U.S. retail crypto trading and 24% of equity options.\n*   **Increased Customer Engagement and Assets:** Funded customers increased by 10% year-over-year to 26.8 million, and total platform assets surged by 119% to $333 billion, driven by continued net deposits and higher valuations.\n*   **Strategic Investments:** Robinhood is investing in product development, international expansion, and new asset classes like tokenized equities.\n\n**Forward-Looking Growth Estimates for 2026:**\n\nAnalysts are optimistic about Robinhood's continued growth into 2026:\n\n*   **Revenue Growth:** Bernstein analysts project Robinhood's revenue to surge from $2.9 billion in 2024 to $6.8 billion by 2026, representing a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of over 51.7%.\n*   **Earnings Growth:** The Zacks Consensus Estimate for Robinhood's 2026 earnings implies year-over-year growth of 16.2%.\n*   **Price Targets:** Wall Street analysts have a bullish consensus with a median price target of $154.50 for HOOD, with some projections as high as $180.00. Mizuho reiterated an Outperform rating and a $172.00 price target, raising its 2026-2027 revenue estimates by 6-7% due to prediction markets growth.\n*   **Diversification Goals:** Robinhood aims to generate over 50% of its revenue from outside the U.S. and from institutional investors within 10 years.\n\nWhile there are some regulatory headwinds concerning prediction markets in certain states, the overall outlook for Robinhood's growth, driven by its diversified operational improvements and strategic initiatives, remains strong for
